remarks: A wff of the form ` A || ( B - C ) ` is interpreted as a congruential equation.  This is similar to ` ( B mod A ) = ( C mod A ) ` , but is defined such that behavior is regular for zero and negative values of ` A ` .  To use this concept effectively, we need to show that congruential equations behave similarly to normal equations; first a transitivity law.  Idea for the future:  If there was a congruential equation symbol, it could incorporate type constraints, so that most of these would not need them.  (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 1-Oct-2014.)
statement: congtr $p |- ( ( ( A e. ZZ /\ B e. ZZ ) /\ ( C e. ZZ /\ D e. ZZ ) /\ ( A || ( B - C ) /\ A || ( C - D ) ) ) -> A || ( B - D ) ) $.
